And twenty of theſe punie lies ile tell,
that men ſhall ſweare I haue diſcontinued ſchoole
aboue a twelue-moneth: I haue within my minde
a thouſand raw tricks of theſe bragging lacks,
vvhich I will practiſe.

sp.speaker: Nerriſſ.
sp.l: Why, ſhall we turne to men?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: Fie, what a queſtion's that,
if thou wert nere a lewd interpreter:
But come, ile tell thee all my my whole deuice
vvhen I am in my coach, which ſtayes for vs
at the Parke gate; and therefore haſt away,
for we muſt meaſure twenty miles to day

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Yes truly, for looke you, the ſinnes of the Father are to be laid vpon the children, therefore I promiſe you, I feare you, I was alwaies plaine with you, and ſo now I ſpeake my agitation of the matter: therefore be a good chere, for truly I thinke you are damnd, there is but one hope in it that can doe you any good, and
that is but a kinde of baſtard hope neither.

sp.speaker: Ieſſica.
sp.p: And what hope is that I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Marry you may partly hope that your Father got you not, that you are not the Iewes daughter.

sp.speaker: Jeſſica.
sp.p: That were a kind of baſtard hope in deede, ſo the ſinnes of my mother ſhould be viſited vpon me.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Truly then I feare you are damnd both by father and mother: thus when I ſhun Scilla your father, I fall into Caribdis your mother; well, you are gone both wayes.

sp.speaker: Ieſſica.
sp.p: I ſhall be ſau'd by my husband, he hath made me a Chriſtian?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Truly the more to blame he, we were Chriſtians enow before, in as many as could well liue one by another: this making of Chriſtians will raiſe the price of Hogs, if we grow all to be pork eaters, we ſhall not ſhortly haue a raſher on the coles for mony.

sp.speaker: Ieſſi.
sp.p: Ile tell my husband Launcelet what you ſay, here he come?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: I ſhall grow iealious of you ſhortly Launcelet, if you thus get my wife into corners?

sp.speaker: Jeſſica.
sp.p: Nay, you neede not feare vs Lorenzo, Launcelet and I are out, he tells me flatly there's no mercy for mee in heauen, becauſe I am a Iewes daughter: and he ſayes you are no good member of the common-wealth, for in conuerting Iewes to Chriſtians, you raiſe the price of porke.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: I ſhall aunſwere that better to the common-wealth than you can the getting vp of the Negroes belly: the Moore is vvith child by you Launcelet?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: It is much that the Moore ſhould be more then reaſon: but if ſhe be leſſe then an honeſt woman, ſhe is indeede more then I tooke her for.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: How euery foole can play vpon the word, I thinke the beſt grace of wit will ſhortly turne into ſilence, and diſcourſe grow commendable in none onely but Parrats: goe in ſirra, bid them prepare for dinner?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: That is done ſir, they haue all ſtomacks?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: Goodly Lord what a wit ſnapper are you, than bid them prepare dinner?
sp.l: to offices of tender curteſie:
We all expect a gentle aunſwere Iewe?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: I haue poſſeſt your grace of what I purpoſe,
and by our holy Sabaoth haue I ſworne
to haue the due and forfet of my bond,
if you deny it, let the danger light
vpon your charter and your Citties freedome?
Youle aske me why I rather chooſe to haue
a weight of carrion fleſh, then to receaue
three thouſand ducats: Ile not aunſwer that?
But ſay it is my humour, is it aunſwerd?
What if my houſe be troubled with a Rat,
and I be pleaſd to giue ten thouſand ducats
to haue it baind? vvhat, are you aunſwerd yet?
Some men there are loue not a gaping pigge?
Some that are mad if they behold a Cat?
And others when the bagpipe ſings ith noſe,
cannot containe their vrine for affection.
Maiſters of paſſion ſwayes it to the moode
of what it likes or loathes, now for your aunſwer:
As there is no firme reaſon to be rendred
vvhy he cannot abide a gaping pigge?
vvhy he a harmeleſſe neceſſarie Cat?
vvhy he a woollen bagpipe: but of force
muſt yeeld to ſuch in euitable ſhame,
as to offend himſelfe being offended:
So can I giue no reaſon, nor I will not,
more then a lodgd hate, and a certaine loathing
I beare Anthonio, that I follow thus
a looſing ſute againſt him? are you aunſwered?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: This is no aunſwer thou vnfeeling man,
to excuſe the currant of thy cruelty?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: I am not bound to pleaſe thee with my anſwers?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Doe all men kill the things they doe not loue?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Euery offence is not a hate at firſt?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou haue a ſerpent ſting thee twice?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I pray you think you queſtion with the Iewe,
you may as well goe ſtand vpon the Beach
and bid the maine flood bate his vſuall height,
vvell vſe queſtion with the Woolfe,
the Ewe bleake for the Lambe:
You may as well forbid the mountaine of Pines
to wag their high tops, and to make no noiſe
vvhen they are fretten with the guſts of heauen:
You may as well doe any thing moſt hard
as ſeeke to ſoften that then which what's harder:
his Iewiſh hart? therefore I doe beſeech you
make no moe offers, vſe no farther meanes,
but will all briefe and plaine conueniencie
let me haue iudgement, and the Iewe his will?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: For thy three thouſand ducats heere is ſixe?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: If euery ducat in ſixe thouſand ducats
vvere in ſixe parts, and euery part a ducat,
I would not draw them, I would haue my bond?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How ſhalt thou hope for mercy rendring none?

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.l: What iudgment ſhall I dread doing no wrong?
you haue among you many a purchaſt ſlaue,
vvhich like your Aſſes, and your Dogs and Mules
you vſe in abiect and in ſlauiſh parts,
becauſe you bought them, ſhall I ſay to you,
let them be free, marry them to your heires?
vvhy ſweat they vnder burthens, let their beds
be made as ſoft as yours, and let their pallats
be ſeaſond with ſuch viands, you will aunſwer
the ſlaues are ours, ſo doe I aunſwer you:
The pound of fleſh which I demaund of him
is deerely bought, as mine and I will haue it:
if you deny me, fie vpon your Law,
there is no force in the decrees of Venice:
I ſtand for iudgement, aunſwer, ſhall I haue it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Vpon my power I may diſmiſſe this Court,
vnleſſe Bellario a learned Doctor,
whom I haue ſent for to determine this
Come heere to day?

sp.speaker: Salerio.
sp.l: My Lord, heere ſtayes without
a meſſenger with letters from the Doctor,
new come from Padua?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring vs the letters? call the Meſſenger?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Good cheere Anthonio? what man, courage yet:
The Iew ſhall haue my fleſh, blood, bones and all,
ere thou ſhalt looſe for me one drop of blood?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am a tainted vveather of the flocke,
meeteſt for death, the weakeſt kind of fruite
drops earlieſt to the ground, and ſo let me;
You cannot better be imployd Baſſanio,
then to liue ſtill and write mine Epitaph?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Came you from Padua from Bellario?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: From both? my L. Bellario greetes your grace?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Why dooſt thou whet thy knife ſo earneſtly?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: To cut the forfaiture from that bankrout there?

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: Not on thy ſoule: but on thy ſoule harſh Iew
thou makſt thy knife keene: but no mettell can,
no, not the hangmans axe beare halfe the keeneneſſe
of thy ſharpe enuie: can no prayers pearce thee?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: No, none that thou haſt wit enough to make▪

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: O be thou damnd, inexecrable dogge,
And for thy life let iuſtice be accuſd;
Thou almoſt mak'ſt me wauer in my faith,
to hold opinion with Pythagoras,
that ſoules of Animalls infuſe themſelues
into the trunks of men: Thy curriſh ſpirit
gouernd a Woolfe, who hangd for humaine ſlaughter
euen from the gallowes did his fell ſoule fleete,
and whileſt thou layeſt in thy vnhallowed dam;
infuſd it ſelfe in thee: for thy deſires
are vvoluiſh, bloody, ſtaru'd, and rauenous.

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Till thou canſt raile the ſeale from off my bond,
Thou but offendſt thy lungs to ſpeake ſo loud:
Repaire thy wit good youth, or it will fall
to cureleſſe ruine. I ſtand heere for law.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This letter from Bellario doth commend
a young and learned Doctor to our Court:
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: He attendeth here hard by
to know your aunſwer whether youle admit him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: With all my hart: ſome three or foure of you
goe giue him curteous conduct to this place,
meane time the Court ſhall heare Bellarios letter.
sp.p: Your Grace ſhall vnderſtand, that at the receit of your letter I am very ſicke, but in the inſtant that your meſſenger came, in louing viſitation was with me a young Doctor of Rome, his name is Balthazer: I acquainted him with the cauſe in cōtrouerſie between the Iew and Anthonio the Merchant, wee turnd ore many bookes together, hee is furniſhed with my opinion, which bettered vvith his owne learning, the greatnes whereof I cannot enough commend, comes with him at my importunitie, to fill vp your graces requeſt in my ſtead. I beſeech you let his lacke of yeeres be no impediment to let him lacke a reuerend eſtimation, for I neuer knew ſo young a body with ſo olde a head: I leaue him to your gracious acceptance, whoſe tryall ſhall better publiſh his commendation.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You heare the learnd Bellario what he writes,
and heere I take it is the doctor come.
Giue me your hand, come you from old Bellario?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are welcome, take your place:
are you acquainted with the difference
that holds this preſent queſtion in the Court.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am enformed throughly of the cauſe,
vvhich is the Merchant here? and which the Iew?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Anthonio and old Shylocke, both ſtand forth.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is your name Shylocke?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Shylocke is my name.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Of a ſtrange nature is the ſute you follow,
yet in ſuch rule, that the Venetian law
cannot impugne you as you doe proceed.
You ſtand within his danger, doe you not.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I, ſo he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Doe you confeſſe the bond?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I doe.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then muſt the Iew be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: On what compulſion muſt I, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The qualitie of mercie is not ſtraind,
it droppeth as the gentle raine from heauen
vpon the place beneath: it is twiſe bleſt,
it bleſſeth him that giues, and him that takes,
tis mightieſt in the mightieſt, it becomes
the throned Monarch better then his crowne.
His ſcepter ſhowes the force of temporall power,
the attribut to awe and maieſtie,
vvherein doth ſit the dread and feare of Kings:
but mercie is aboue this ſceptred ſway,
it is enthroned in the harts of Kings,
it is an attribut to God himſelfe;
and earthly power doth then ſhow likeſt gods
vvhen mercie ſeaſons iuſtice: therefore Jew,
though iuſtice be thy plea, conſider this,
that in the courſe of iuſtice, none of vs
ſhould ſee ſaluation: vve doe pray for mercy,
and that ſame prayer, doth teach vs all to render
the deedes of mercie. I haue ſpoke thus much
to mittigate the iuſtice of thy plea,
vvhich if thou follow, this ſtrict Court of Venice
muſt needes giue ſentence gainſt the Merchant there.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: My deeds vpon my head, I craue the law,
the penalty and forfaite of my bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is he not able to diſcharge the money?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Yes, heere I tender it for him in the Court,
yea, twiſe the ſumme, if that will not ſuffiſe,
I will be bound to pay it ten times ore
on forfait of my hands, my head, my hart,
if this will not ſuffiſe, it muſt appeare
that malice beares downe truth. And I beſeech you
wreſt once the law to your authoritie,
to doe a great right, doe a little wrong,
and curbe this cruell deuill of his will.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It muſt not be, there is no power in Venice
can altar a decree eſtabliſhed:
twill be recorded for a precedent,
and many an errour by the ſame example
will ruſh into the ſtate, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: A Daniell come to iudgement: yea a Daniell.
O wiſe young Iudge how I doe honour thee.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I pray you let me looke vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Heere tis moſt reuerend doctor, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Shylocke theres thrice thy money offred thee.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: An oath, an oath, I haue an oath in heauen,
ſhall I lay periurie vpon my ſoule?
Not not for Venice.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why this bond is forfait,
and lawfully by this the Iew may claime
a pound of fleſh, to be by him cut off
neereſt the Merchants hart: be mercifull,
take thrice thy money, bid me teare the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: When it is payd, according to the tenure.
It doth appeare you are a worthy iudge,
you know the law, your expoſition
hath beene moſt ſound: I charge you by the law,
vvhereof you are a well deſeruing piller,
proceede to iudgement: by my ſoule I ſweare,
there is no power in the tongue of man
to alter me, I ſtay here on my Bond,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Moſt hartelie I doe beſeech the Court
to giue the iudgement.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why than thus it is,
you muſt prepare your boſome▪ for his knife.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: O noble Iudge, ô excellent young man.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: For the intent and purpoſe of the law
hath full relation to the penaltie,
vvhich heere appeareth due vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Tis very true: o wiſe and vpright Iudge,
how much more elder art thou then thy lookes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore lay bare your boſome.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I, his breaſt,
ſo ſayes the bond, doth it not noble Iudge?
Neereſt his hart, thoſe are the very words.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is ſo, are there ballance here to weigh the fleſh?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I haue them ready.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Haue by ſome Surgion Shylocke on your charge,
to ſtop his wounds, leaſt he doe bleede to death.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Is it ſo nominated in the bond?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is not ſo expreſt, but what of that?
Twere good you doe ſo much for charitie.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I cannot finde it, tis not in the bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You Merchant, haue you any thing to ſay?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But little; I am armd and well prepard,
giue me your hand Baſſanio, far you well,
greeue not that I am falne to this for you:
for heerein Fortune ſhowes her ſelfe more kind
then is her cuſtome: it is ſtill her vſe
to let the wretched man out-liue his wealth,
to view with hollow eye and wrinckled brow
an age of pouertie: from which lingring pennance
of ſuch miſery doth ſhe cut me of.
Commend me to your honourable wife,
tell her the proceſſe of Anthonios end,
ſay how I lou'd you, ſpeake me faire in death:
and when the tale is told, bid her be iudge
vvhether Baſſanio had not once a loue:
Repent but you that you ſhall looſe your friend
and he repents not that he payes your debt.
For if the Iew doe cut but deepe enough,
Ile pay it inſtantly with all my hart.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Anthonio, I am married to a wife
which is as deere to me as life it ſelfe,
but life it ſelfe, my wife, and all the world,

are not with m ••
• ſteemd aboue thy life.
I would looſe al • I ſacrifize them all
heere to this deuill, to deliuer you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your wife would giue you little thankes for that
if ſhe were by to heare you make the offer.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I haue a wife who I proteſt I loue,
I would ſhe were in heauen, ſo ſhe could
intreate ſome power to change this curriſh Iew.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Tis well you offer it behind her back,
the wiſh would make elſe an vnquiet houſe.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Theſe be the chriſtian husbands, I haue a daughter
vvould any of the ſtocke of Barrabas
had beene her husband, rather then a Chriſtian.
We trifle time, I pray thee purſue ſentence.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A pound of that ſame Merchants fleſh is thine,
the Court awards it, and the law doth giue it.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Moſt rightfull Iudge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: And you muſt cut this fleſh from off his breaſt,
the law alowes it, and the court awards it.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Moſt learned Iudge, a ſentence, come prepare.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry a little, there is ſome thing elſe,
this bond doth giue thee heere no iote of blood,
the words expreſly are a pound of fleſh:
take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of fleſh,
but in the cutting it, if thou dooſt ſhed
one drop of Chriſtian blood, thy lands and goods
are by the lawes of Venice confiſcate
vnto the ſtate of Venice.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O vpright Iudge,
Marke Iew, ô learned Iudge.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Is that the law?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thy ſelfe ſhalt ſee the Act:
for as thou vrgeſt iuſtice, be aſſurd
thou ſhalt haue iuſtice more then thou deſirſt.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O learned iudge, mark Iew, a learned iudge.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I take this offer then, pay the bond thrice
and let the Chriſtian goe.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Heere is the money.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Soft, the Iew ſhal haue all iuſtice, ſoft no haſt,
he ſhall haue nothing but the penalty.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O Iew, an vpright Iudge, a learned Iudge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore prepare thee to cut of the fleſh,
Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou leſſe nor more
but iuſt a pound of fleſh: if thou tak'ſt more
or leſſe then a iuſt pound, be it but ſo much
as makes it light of heauy in the ſubſtance,
or the deuiſion of the twentith part
of one poore ſcruple, nay if the ſcale doe turne
but in the eſtimation of a hayre,
thou dyeſt, and all thy goods are confiſcate.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A ſecond Daniell, a Daniell Iew,
now infidell I haue you on the hip.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why doth the Iew pauſe, take thy forfaiture.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Giue me my principall, and let me goe.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: I haue it ready for thee, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Hee hath refuſd it in the open Court,
hee ſhall haue meerely iuſtice and his bond.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A Daniell ſtill ſay I, a ſecond Daniell,
I thanke thee Iew for teaching me that word.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Shall I not haue barely my principall?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt haue nothing but the forfaiture
to be ſo taken at thy perrill Iew.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Why then the deuill giue him good of it:
Ile ſtay no longer queſtion.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry Iew,
the law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the lawes of Venice,
if it be proued againſt an alien,
that by direct, or indirect attempts
he ſeeke the life of any Citizen,
the party gainſt the which he doth contriue,
ſhall ſeaze one halfe his goods, the other halfe
comes to the priuie cofler of the State,
and the offenders life lies in the mercy
of the Duke onely, gainſt all other voyce.
In which predicament I ſay thou ſtandſt:
for it appeares by manifeſt proceeding,
that indirectly, and directly to
thou haſt contriued againſt the very life
of the defendant: and thou haſt incurd
the danger formorly by me rehearſt.
Downe therefore, and beg mercie of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Beg that thou maiſt haue leaue to hang thy ſelfe,
and yet thy wealth beeing forfait to the ſtate,
thou haſt not left the value of a cord,
therefore thou muſt be hangd at the ſtates charge.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That thou ſhalt ſee the difference of our ſpirit
I pardon thee thy life before thou aske it:
for halfe thy wealth, it is Anthonios,
the other halfe comes to the generall ſtate,
vvhich humblenes may driue vnto a fine.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I for the ſtate, not for Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that,
you take my houſe, when you doe take the prop
that doth ſuſtaine my houſe: you take my life
vvhen you doe take the meanes whereby I liue.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What mercy can you render him Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A halter gratis, nothing elſe for Godſake.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So pleaſe my Lord the Duke, & all the Court
to quit the fine for one halfe of his goods,
I am content: ſo he will let me haue
the other halfe in vſe, to render it
vpon his death vnto the Gentleman
that lately ſtole his daughter.
Two things prouided more, that for this fauour
he preſently become a Chriſtian:
the other, that he doe record a gift
heere in the Court of all he dies poſſeſt
vnto his ſonne Lorenzo and his daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He ſhall doe this, or elſe I doe recant
the pardon that I late pronounced heere.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Art thou contented Iew? what doſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Clarke, draw a deede of gift.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I pray you giue me leaue to goe from hence,
I am not well, ſend the deede after me,
and I will ſigne it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Get thee gone, but doe it.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: In chriſtning ſhalt thou haue two Godfathers,
had I beene iudge, thou ſhouldſt haue had ten more,
to bring thee to the gallowes, not to the font.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir I entreate you home with me to dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I humbly doe deſire your Grace of pardon,
I muſt away this night toward Padua,
and it is meete I preſently ſet forth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am ſorry that your leyſure ſerues you not.
Anthonio, gratifie this gentleman,
for in my mind you are much bound to him.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Moſt worthy gentleman, I and my friend
haue by your wiſedome been this day aquitted
of greeuous penalties, in Iewe whereof,
three thouſand ducats due vnto the Iew
wee freely cope your curtious paines withall.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And ſtand indebted ouer and aboue
in loue and ſeruice to you euer-more.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Hee is well payd that is well ſatisfied,
and I deliuering you, am ſatisfied,
and therein doe account my ſelfe well payd,
my minde was neuer yet more mercinarie.
I pray you know me when we meete againe,
I wiſh you well, and ſo I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Deere ſir, of force I muſt attempt you further,
take ſome remembrance of vs as a tribute,
not as fee: graunt me two things I pray you,
not to deny me, and to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You preſſe me farre, and therefore I wil yeeld,
giue mee your gloues, Ile weare them for your ſake,
and for your loue ile take this ring from you,
doe not draw back your hand, ile take no more,
and you in loue ſhall not denie me this?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: This ring good ſir, alas it is a trifle,
I will not ſhame my ſelfe to giue you this?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will haue nothing elſe but onely this,
and now me thinks I haue a minde to it?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: There's more depends on this then on the valew,
the deareſt ring in Venice will I giue you,
and finde it out by proclamation,
onely for this I pray you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I ſee ſir you are liberall in offers,
you taught me firſt to beg, and now me thinks
you teach me how a begger ſhould be aunſwerd.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Good ſir, this ring was giuen me by my wife,
and when ſhe put it on, ſhe made me vowe
that I ſhould neither ſell, nor giue, nor looſe it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That ſcuſe ſerues many men to ſaue their gifts,
and if your wife be not a mad woman,
and know how well I haue deſeru'd this ring,
ſhe would not hold out enemy for euer
for giuing it to me: vvell, peace be with you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My L. Baſſanio, let him haue the ring,
let his deſeruings and my loue withall
be valued gainſt your wiues commaundement.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Goe Gratiano, runne and ouer-take him,
giue him the ring, and bring him if thou canſt
vnto Anthonios houſe, away, make haſt.
Come, you and I will thither preſently,
and in the morning early will we both
flie toward Belmont, come Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Enquire the Iewes houſe out, giue him this deed,
and let him ſigne it, weele away to night,
and be a day before our husbands home:
this deede will be well welcome to Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Faire ſir, you are well ore-tane:
My L. Baſſanio vpon more aduice,
hath ſent you heere this ring, and doth intreate
your company at dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That cannot be;
his ring I doe accept moſt thankfully,
and ſo I pray you tell him: furthermore,
I pray you ſhew my youth old Shylockes houſe.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: That will I doe.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Sir, I would ſpeake with you:
Ile ſee if I can get my husbands ring
vvhich I did make him ſweare to keepe for euer.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou maiſt I warrant, we ſhal haue old ſwearing
that they did giue the rings away to men;
but wele out-face them, and out-ſweare them to:
away, make haſt, thou knowſt where I will tarry.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Come good ſir, will yov ſhew me to this houſe.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The moone ſhines bright. In ſuch a night as this,
vvhen the ſweet winde did gently kiſſe the trees,
and they did make no noyſe, in ſuch a night
Troylus me thinks mounted the Troian walls,
and ſigh'd his ſoule toward the Grecian tents
vvhere Creſſed lay that night.

sp.speaker: Jeſſi.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
did Thiſbie fearefully ore-trip the dewe,
and ſaw the Lyons ſhadow ere him ſelfe,
and ranne diſmayed away.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
ſtoode Dido with a willow in her hand
vpon the wilde ſea banks, and waft her Loue
to come againe to Carthage.

sp.speaker: Ieſſi.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
Medea gathered the inchanted hearbs
that did renew old Eſon.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
did Ieſſica ſteale from the wealthy Iewe,
and with an vnthrift loue did runne from Venice,
as farre as Belmont.

sp.speaker: Ieſſi.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
did young Lorenzo ſweare he loued her well,
ſtealing her ſoule with many vowes of faith,
and nere a true one.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In ſuch a night
did pretty Ieſſica (like a little ſhrow)
ſlaunder her Loue, and he forgaue it her.

sp.speaker: Ieſſi.
sp.l: I would out-night you did no body come:
But harke, I heare the footing of a man.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes ſo faſt in ſilence of the night?

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: A friend?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: A friend, what friend, your name I pray you friend?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
my Miſtres will before the breake of day
be heere at Belmont, ſhe doth ſtray about
by holy croſſes where ſhe kneeles and prayes
for happy wedlock houres.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes with her?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: None but a holy Hermit and her mayd:
I pray you is my Maiſter yet returnd?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: He is not, nor we haue not heard from him,
But goe we in I pray thee Ieſſica,
and ceremoniouſly let vs prepare
ſome welcome for the Miſtres of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Sola, ſola: wo ha, ho ſola, ſola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sola, did you ſee M. Lorenzo, & M. Lorenzo ſola, ſola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Leaue hollowing man, heere.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Sola, where, where?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Heere?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tell him there's a Poſt come from my Maiſter, with his horne full of good newes, my Maiſter will be heere ere morning ſweete ſoule.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Let's in, and there expect their comming.
And yet no matter: why ſhould we goe in.
My friend Stephen, ſignifie pray you
vvithin the houſe, your miſtres is at hand,
and bring your muſique foorth into the ayre.
How ſweet the moone-light ſleepes vpon this banke,
heere will we ſit, and let the ſounds of muſique
creepe in our eares ſoft ſtilnes, and the night
become the tutches of ſweet harmonie:
ſit Ieſſica, looke how the floore of heauen
is thick inlayed with pattens of bright gold,
there's not the ſmalleſt orbe which thou beholdſt
but in his motion like an Angell ſings,
ſtill quiring to the young eyde Cherubins;
ſuch harmonie is in immortall ſoules,
but whilſt this muddy veſture of decay
dooth groſly cloſe it in, we cannot heare it:
Come hoe, and wake Diana with a himne,
vvith ſweeteſt tutches pearce your miſtres eare,
and draw her home with muſique.

sp.speaker: Ieſſi.
sp.l: I am neuer merry when I heare ſweet muſique.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: The reaſon is▪ your ſpirits are attentiue:
for doe but note a wild and wanton heard
or race of youthfull and vnhandled colts
fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neghing loude,
vvhich is the hote condition of their blood,
if they but heare perchance a trumpet ſound,
or any ayre of muſique touch their eares,
you ſhall perceaue them make a mutuall ſtand,
their ſauage eyes turn'd to a modeſt gaze,
by the ſweet power of muſique: therefore the Poet
did faine that Orpheus drew trees, ſtones, and floods.
Since naught ſo ſtockiſh hard and full of rage,
but muſique for the time doth change his nature,
the man that hath no muſique in himſelfe,
nor is not moued with concord of ſweet ſounds,
is fit for treaſons, ſtratagems, and ſpoiles,
the motions of his ſpirit are dull as night,
and his affections darke as Terebus:
let no ſuch man be truſted: marke the muſique.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That light we ſee is burning in my hall:
how farre that little candell throwes his beames,
ſo ſhines a good deede in a naughty world.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: When the moone ſhone we did not ſee the candle?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: So dooth the greater glory dim the leſſe,
a ſubſtitute ſhines brightly as a King
vntill a King be by, and then his ſtate
empties it ſelfe, as doth an inland brooke
into the maine of waters: muſique harke.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: It is your muſique Madame of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Nothing is good I ſee without reſpect,
me thinks it ſounds much ſweeter then by day?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Silence beſtowes that vertue on it Madam?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The Crow doth ſing as ſweetly as the Larke
vvhen neither is attended: and I thinke
the Nightingale if ſhe ſhould ſing by day
vvhen euery Gooſe is cackling, would be thought
no better a Muſition then the Renne?
How many things by ſeaſon, ſeaſond are
to their right prayſe, and true perfection:
Peace, how the moone ſleepes with Endimion,
and would not be awak'd.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: That is the voyce,
or I am much deceau'd of Portia.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He knowes me as the blind man knowes the Cuckoe
by the bad voyce?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Deere Lady welcome home?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We haue bin praying for our husbands welfare,
vvhich ſpeed we hope the better for our words:
are they return'd?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Madam, they are not yet:
but there is come a Meſſenger before
to ſignifie their comming?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Goe in Nerriſſa.
Giue order to my ſeruants, that they take
no note at all of our being abſent hence,
nor you Lorenzo, Jeſſica nor you.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Your husband is at hand, I heare his trumpet,
vve are no tell-tales Madame, feare you not.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: This night me thinks is but the day light ſicke,
it lookes a little paler, tis a day,
ſuch as the day is when the ſunne is hid.

div.stage: Enter Baſſanio, Anthonio, Gratiano, and their followers.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: We ſhould hold day with the Antipodes,
if you would walke in abſence of the ſunne.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let me giue light, but let me not be light,
for a light wife doth make a heauie husband,
and neuer be Baſſanio ſo for me,
but God ſort all: you are welcome home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: I thank you Madam, giue welcome to my friend,
this is the man, this is Anthonio,
to whom I am ſo infinitely bound.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You ſhould in all ſence be much bound to him,
for as I heare he was much bound for you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No more then I am well acquitted of.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, you are very welcome to our houſe:
it muſt appeare in other wayes then words,
therefore I ſcant this breathing curteſie.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: By yonder moone I ſweare you doe me wrong,
infaith I gaue it to the Iudges Clarke,
vvould he were gelt that had it for my part,
ſince you doe take it Loue ſo much at hart.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A quarrell hoe already, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: About a hoope of gold, a paltry ring
that ſhe did giue me, whoſe poſie was
for all the world like Cutlers poetry
vpon a knife, Loue me, and leaue me not.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: What talke you of the poſie or the valew:
You ſwore to me when I did giue you,
that you would weare it till your houre of death,
and that it ſhould lie with you in your graue,
though not for me, yet for your vehement oathes,
you ſhould haue beene reſpectiue and haue kept it.
Gaue it a Iudges Clarke: no Gods my Iudge
the Clarke will nere weare haire ons face that had it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: He will, and if he liue to be a man.

sp.speaker: Nerriſſa.
sp.l: I, if a woman liue to be a man.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Now by this hand I gaue it to a youth,
a kind of boy, a little ſcrubbed boy,
no higher then thy ſelfe, the Iudges Clarke,
a prating boy that begd it as a fee,
I could not for my hart deny it him.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You were to blame, I muſt be plaine with you,
to part ſo ſlightly with your wiues firſt gift,
a thing ſtuck on with oaths vpon your finger,
and ſo riueted with faith vnto your fleſh.
I gaue my Loue a ring, and made him ſweare
neuer to part with it, and heere he ſtands:
I dare be ſworne for him he would not leaue it,
nor pluck it from his finger, for the wealth
that the world maiſters. Now in faith Gratiano
you giue your wife too vnkind a cauſe of griefe,
and twere to me I ſhould be mad at it.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Why I were beſt to cut my left hand off,
and ſweare I loſt the ring defending it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: My Lord Baſſanio gaue his ring away
vnto the Iudge that begd it, and indeede
deſeru'd it to? and then the boy his Clarke
that tooke ſome paines in writing, he begd mine,
and neither man nor maiſter would take ought
but the two rings.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What ring gaue you my Lord?
Not that I hope which you receau'd of me.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: If I could add a lie vnto a fault,
I would deny it: but you ſee my finger
hath not the ring vpon it, it is gone.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Euen ſo voyd is your falſe hart of truth.
By heauen I will nere come in your bed
vntill I ſee the ring?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Nor I in yours
till I againe ſee mine?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Sweet Portia,
if you did know to whom I gaue the ring,
if you did know for whom I gaue the ring,
and would conceaue for what I gaue the ring,
and how vnwillingly I left the ring,
vvhen naught would be accepted but the ring,
you would abate the ſtrength of your diſpleaſure?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If you had knowne the vertue of the ring,
or halfe her worthines that gaue the ring,
or your owne honour to containe the ring,
you would not then haue parted with the ring:
vvhat man is there ſo much vnreaſonable
if you had pleaſd to haue defended it
vvith any termes of zeale: wanted the modeſty
to vrge the thing held as a ceremonie:
Nerriſſa teaches me what to beleeue,
ile die for't, but ſome woman had the ring?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: No by my honour Madam, by my ſoule
no woman had it, but a ciuill Doctor,
vvhich did refuſe three thouſand ducats of me,
and begd the ring, the which I did denie him,
and ſufferd him to goe diſpleaſd away,
euen he that had held vp the very life
of my deere friend. What ſhould I ſay ſweet Lady,
I was inforc'd to ſend it after him,
I was beſet with ſhame and curteſie,
my honour would not let ingratitude
ſo much beſmere it: pardon me good Lady,
for by theſe bleſſed candels of the night,
had you been there, I think you would haue begd
the ring of me to giue the worthy Doctor?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let not that Doctor ere come neere my houſe
ſince he hath got the iewell that I loued,
and that which you did ſweare to keepe for me,
I will become as liberall as you,
Ile not deny him any thing I haue,
no, not my body, nor my husbands bed:
Know him I ſhall, I am well ſure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argos,
if you doe not, if I be left alone,
now by mine honour which is yet mine owne.
ile haue that Doctor for mine bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Nerriſſa.
sp.l: And I his Clark: therefore be well aduiſd
how you doe leaue me to mine owne protection.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Well doe you ſo: let not me take him then,
for if I doe, ile mar the young Clarks pen.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I am th'vnhappy ſubiect of theſe quarrells.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, greeue not you, you are welcome notwithſtanding.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Portia, forgiue me this enforced wrong,
and in the hearing of theſe many friends
I ſweare to thee, euen by thine owne faire eyes
vvherein I ſee my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Marke you but that?
In both my eyes he doubly ſees himſelfe:
In each eye one, ſweare by your double ſelfe,
and there's an oath of credite.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me.
Pardon this fault, and by my ſoule I ſweare
I neuer more will breake an oath with thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I once did lend my body for his wealth,
vvhich but for him that had your husbands ring
had quite miſcaried. I dare be bound againe,
my ſoule vpon the forfet, that your Lord
vvill neuer more breake faith aduiſedly.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then you ſhall be his ſurety: giue him this,
and bid him keepe it better then the other.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Here Lord Baſſanio, ſweare to keepe this ring.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: By heauen it is the ſame I gaue the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I had it of him: pardon me Baſſanio,
for by this ring the Doctor lay with me.

sp.speaker: Nerriſſa.
sp.l: And pardon me my gentle Gratiano,
for that ſame ſcrubbed boy the Doctors Clarke
in liew of this, laſt night did he with me.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Why this is like the mending of high wayes
in Sommer where the wayes are faire enough?
What, are we cuckolds ere we haue deſeru'd it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Speake not ſo groſly, you are all amaz'd;
Heere is a letter, reade it at your leaſure,
It comes from Padua from Bellario,
there you ſhall finde that Portia was the Doctor,
Nerriſſa there her Clarke. Lorenzo heere
ſhall witnes I ſet foorth as ſoone as you,
and euen but now returnd: I haue not yet
enterd my houſe. Anthonio you are welcome,
and I haue better newes in ſtore for you
than you exſpect: vnſeale this letter ſoone,
there you ſhall finde three of your Argoſies
are richly come to harbour ſodainly.
You ſhall not know by what ſtrange accident
I chaunced on this letter.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am dumb?

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: Were you the Doctor, and I knew you not?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Were you the Clark that is to make me cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: I but the Clarke that neuer meanes to doe it,
vnleſſe he liue vntill he be a man.

sp.speaker: Baſſ.
sp.l: (Sweet Doctor) you ſhall be my bedfellow,
vvhen I am abſent then lie with my wife.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: (Sweet Lady) you haue giuen me life and lyuing;
for heere I reade for certaine that my ſhips
are ſafely come to Rode.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How now Lorenzo?
my Clarke hath ſome good comforts to for you.

sp.speaker: Ner
sp.l: I, and ile giue them him without a fee.
There doe I giue to you and Ieſſica
from the rich Iewe, a ſpeciall deede of gift
after his death, of all he dies poſſeſt of.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Faire Ladies, you drop Manna in the way
of ſtarued people.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is almoſt morning,
and yet I am ſure you are not ſatisfied
of theſe euents at full. Let vs goe in,
and charge vs there vpon intergotories,
and we will aunſwer all things faithfully.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Let it be ſo, the firſt intergory
that my Nerriſſa ſhall be ſworne on, is,
vvhether till the next night ſhe had rather ſtay,
or goe to bed now being two houres to day:
But were the day come, I ſhould wiſh it darke
till I were couching with the Doctors Clarke.
Well, while I liue, ile feare no other thing
ſo ſore, as keeping ſafe Nerriſſas ring.
